lodge.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to become firmly stuck somewhere, or to make something become stuck
lodge.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: The fishbone lodged in her throat.
The bullet was lodged in his spine.
lodge.translation[0].definitions[0].note: Lodge is usually passive when used as a transitive verb
lodge.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to provide someone with a place to stay for a short time
lodge.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: a building used to lodge prisoners of war
The refugees were lodged in old army barracks.
lodge.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to put something important in an official place so that it is safe
lodge.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Be sure to lodge a copy of the contract with your solicitor.
The money was lodged in a Swiss bank account.
lodge.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to pay to live in a room in someone’s house
lodge.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: John lodged with a family in Bristol when he first started work.
lodge.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a small house on the land of a large country house, usually at the main entrance gate
lodge.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: a room or small building at the entrance to a college, institution etc for someone whose job is to watch who enters and leaves
lodge.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: a house or hotel in the country or mountains where people can stay when they want to go hunting, shooting etc
lodge.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: a local meeting place for some organizations, or the group of people who belong to one of these organizations
lodge.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: He was a member of a Masonic lodge.
lodge.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: a traditional home of Native Americans, or the group of people that live in it
lodge.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to make a formal or official complaint, protest etc
lodge.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: An appeal must be lodged within 28 days.
lodge.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to formally give information or documents which have to be given by law to an official authority
lodge.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Two companies failed to lodge printed copies of their annual reports by the opening of trading yesterday.
Opening bids will have to be lodged by December 11.
To retain copyright you’ll have to lodge a patent application.
lodge.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: to put money or something valuable in an official place so that it is safe
lodge.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: The money was lodged in an account in Hamburg.
Be sure to lodge a copy of the contract with your solicitor.
